Exactly, should use Tensor.to_current_device() instead.
And allow torch.cuda.set_device() to take tensor object as argument, so that you can set device to that tensor object. But if that tensor object is in CPU memory, then you encounter the same problem.

Then you need to do something as torch.device.set_device().

I am not sure what you guys are thinking. But it is obviously that the original design was not very elegant. And you cannot easily create a tensor object in a device that is the same device as a given tensor object.

body:
Exactly, should use Tensor.to_current_device()  instead.
And allow torch.cuda.set_device() to take tensor object as argument, so that you can set device to that tensor object. But if that tensor object is in CPU memory, then you encounter the same problem.

Then you need to do something as torch.device.set_device().

I am not sure what you guys are thinking. But it is obviously that the original design was not very elegant. And you cannot easily **create a tensor object in a device that is the same device as a given tensor object.**
